title: jQuery Traversing -Siblings

metadata.description: Learn about jQuery Traversing -Siblings with clear explanations and practical examples.

content_sections.title: Details
content_sections.content:
With jQuery you can traverse sideways in the DOM tree to find siblings of an element. Siblings share the same parent. Traversing Sideways in The DOM Tree There are many useful jQuery methods for traversing sideways in the DOM tree: siblings() prev() prevAll() prevUntil() jQuery siblings() Method The siblings() method returns all sibling elements of the selected element. The following example returns all sibling elements of

: Example $(document).ready(function(){ $("h2").siblings(); }); You can also use an optional parameter to filter the search for siblings. The following example returns all sibling elements of

that are

elements: Example $(document).ready(function(){ $("h2").siblings("p"); }); jQuery The method returns the The following example returns the

: Example $(document).ready(function(){ $("h2"). }); jQuery The method returns all The following example returns all

: Example $(document).ready(function(){ $("h2"). }); jQuery The method returns all arguments. The following example returns all sibling elements between a

and a

element: Example $(document).ready(function(){ $("h2"). }); jQuery prev(), prevAll() & prevUntil() Methods The prev() , prevAll() and prevUntil() methods work just like the methods above but with reverse functionality: they return elements in the DOM tree, instead of forward). jQuery Exercises Test Yourself With Exercises Exercise: Use a jQuery method to get all siblings elements of an

element. $("h2"). (); Submit Answer » Start the Exercise jQuery Traversing Reference For a complete overview of all jQuery Traversing methods, please go to our jQuery Traversing Reference . ★ +1

summary: This tutorial covers jQuery Traversing -Siblings concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use jQuery Traversing -Siblings effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of jQuery Traversing -Siblings and how to apply it in your projects.
